stream_context.summary: Kaze implements and iterates on a new “Egg Coin/Yoshi coin” collection mission by adding a 7th act per course and introducing a Sonic Adventure–style proximity radar. He also outlines a coin-driven upgrade/overworld-change economy, discusses demo packaging constraints, and resolves a mysterious dynamic-light object that refused to spawn due to an engine parameter edge case.
stream_context.significance_reason: This stream locks in a structural design change (7 acts instead of 6) to support an “Egg Coin/Yoshi coin” mission with a dedicated radar UI, and it includes a notable technical breakthrough explaining why certain light objects were not spawning.

findings.summary: Kaze changes the act/mission structure from 6 to 7 acts, with the last act always dedicated to collecting Egg Coins/Yoshi coins (“Find the Egg Coins”), and that act grants access to a radar UI.

The radar is explicitly inspired by Sonic Adventure 1’s treasure-hunt radar (Knuckles-style): icons blink faster and shift toward red as the player gets closer to a coin source (including coins held by NPCs like a bunny).

Kaze decides the radar should likely be available automatically (not something the player must buy) to prevent a worst-case experience where a player starts the coin-collection act with no hint system and becomes frustrated.
findings.quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all—that's going to suck.

findings.summary: He acknowledges a tradeoff: making the radar automatic could reduce the value/importance of other items/upgrades (he mentions a “lens” becoming less valuable if the radar is always present).

Coins are planned to have long-term value beyond star collection: Kaze describes spending/donating coins for upgrades and even overworld changes (e.g., funding an NPC to build a bridge, which permanently changes the overworld).
findings.quote: You're actually going to affect the world by giving people money.

findings.summary: Kaze positions the coin economy as a major motivator meant to make coins feel meaningful and exciting rather than incidental collectibles.
findings.quote: Trust me, the coins are not going to feel worthless—the coins are going to feel very cool.

findings.summary: Demo plan/constraint: if players patch or force access to levels that are not included in the demo build, the game will crash because those levels won’t exist in the demo ROM; he also says a future “second demo” will contain only Course 1.
Kaze diagnoses why certain dynamic light objects in a level would not appear: in the SM64 engine, if a behavior parameter is set to 255, the object will not spawn. Adjusting this resolves the issue.
findings.quote: If you set the behavior parameter to 255, the object does not spawn.

findings.summary: UI/readability iteration: the team discusses that rapid blinking “eyes” on the radar may be distracting; Kaze explores alternatives like slower blinking, transparency that increases as you get closer, and brightness/saturation-based proximity feedback.

N64 rendering constraint affects UI animation options: Kaze notes that scaling UI textures can look bad because one texture pixel maps directly to one output pixel on N64, limiting smooth grow/shrink effects for radar icons.
Kaze considers proximity curves using time functions (e.g., sine-squared) to make radar feedback smoother and less abrupt, rather than harsh step changes.

Color-coding is complicated by per-level coin colors and existing radar “heat” colors (green→red) plus separate “collected” states; Kaze worries overlap will confuse players and explores using transparency/halo effects instead of more colors.

Core course roadmap update: Kaze states all main courses are now planned; Course 13 (Ice Castle) is largely done but its outside area isn’t finished, Course 14 (Craft World) is mostly done, and Course 15 (Space Arcade) is still more of a planned pathway needing work.

He confirms a prior mission type is being removed/changed: “100 coin missions do not exist anymore,” with progression/points described as global now (implying a systemic restructure of mission goals and reward economy).

Testing workflow note: Kaze uses Project64 for convenience but relies on Parallel Launcher to ensure the hack runs in a more accuracy-focused environment, despite frustration with frequent launcher update prompts.

biobak.summary: Biobak is actively contributing level assets/layout work during the demo push; Kaze mentions a “line of mushrooms” Biobak is working on that still needs to be placed into the course.
Biobak (via chat) engages with the radar feature discussion; Kaze offers to show the radar and solicits feedback on its behavior/visibility.

zeina.summary: Zeina is present on stream, and Kaze briefly mentions coordinating with her to pick up/handle acquiring a second N64 for testing purposes (suggesting practical support for hardware validation).

key_stories.title: Turning coin hunting into a dedicated 7th act with a proximity radar
key_stories.summary: Kaze rethinks how Yoshi/Egg coins fit into the mission structure: rather than being an optional side-collectible, they become a dedicated act (“Find the Egg Coins”) supported by a proximity radar. He frames it as preventing frustration and ensuring players understand the value of coins and the intended loop.
key_stories.challenge: Players could enter the coin-collection objective without guidance (especially if the radar were a purchasable item), making the mission feel unfair and undermining the coin system’s value.
key_stories.process: He adds a 7th act slot, implements a Sonic Adventure–style radar, then iterates on UI clarity (blink rate, transparency, brightness curves) while debating purchase vs. automatic availability.
key_stories.outcome: Structural decision is implemented (7 acts + radar). UI is still being tuned to avoid distraction and color confusion, but the direction is set: coin hunting is now a formal mission type.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all—that's going to suck.

key_stories.title: Dynamic light objects not spawning due to behavior parameter edge case
key_stories.summary: While polishing a demo course, Kaze investigates why certain decorative/dynamic light objects fail to appear. He traces it to a surprising engine behavior parameter value that silently prevents spawning.
key_stories.challenge: A set of level lights would not spawn/function despite being placed and active for the act, blocking visual polish for the demo.
key_stories.process: He inspects object behavior settings and discovers SM64’s object-spawn logic treats a behavior parameter value of 255 as “do not spawn.” He adjusts the parameter to restore spawning.
key_stories.outcome: Root cause identified and effectively resolved, unblocking dynamic lighting polish for the demo area.
key_stories.key_quote: If you set the behavior parameter to 255, the object does not spawn.

open_questions.topic: Coin economy specifics and overworld change system
open_questions.context: Kaze describes coins being used to buy upgrades and to fund NPC-driven overworld changes (e.g., donating 500 coins to build a bridge), and claims coins will feel more valuable than Mario Odyssey.
questions: What are the full categories of things coins can buy (movement upgrades, hints, cosmetic changes, access gating, world changes)?
How do you prevent coin spending from soft-locking progression (e.g., spending coins on non-essential changes and lacking coins later)?
Are overworld changes permanent per save file, and how do you communicate those changes to the player (cutscenes, NPC dialogue, map updates)?
How did you balance coin costs (like 500 coins) against expected coin income per course/mission? Are there anti-grind principles you’re following?

open_questions.topic: Radar availability vs. purchasable upgrades (and the ‘lens’ item)
open_questions.context: Kaze worries that making the radar automatic could reduce the value of another upgrade (“lens”), yet he wants to avoid players starting the coin mission with no hint system.
questions: What is the ‘lens’ intended to do, and how would a permanent radar undermine it?
Did you prototype a version where the radar is purchasable—what did playtesting (or imagined user flow) reveal?
What is your final rule for when the radar appears (only act 7, always on, toggleable, unlockable globally after first use)?
How do you tutorialize the radar so players understand it without stopping gameplay?

open_questions.topic: Radar UI final language (color, transparency, blinking) under N64 constraints
open_questions.context: The team debates blink distraction, color conflicts with per-level coin colors, and N64 limitations (poor-looking scaling due to texel-to-pixel mapping). Kaze experiments with transparency that increases when closer and with smoother time-based intensity curves.
questions: What final visual signals will you use for proximity: blink speed, brightness, transparency, saturation, sound, or a combination?
How do you distinguish: (1) coin is in another sub-area, (2) coin is nearby, (3) coin already collected, without relying on confusing colors?
Did you consider adding directional information (arrows/compass) and reject it purely on design grounds, or also technical/UI clutter reasons?
Will the radar be adjustable in accessibility settings (reduced blinking, alternate cues)?

open_questions.topic: Demo packaging strategy and crash risk when forcing access to cut content
open_questions.context: Kaze says the demo will crash if players patch/walk into levels not included, and mentions a future demo that only includes Course 1.
questions: What is the exact scope of Demo 1 vs Demo 2 (which courses/areas, which features enabled/disabled)?
Why not stub missing levels with safe placeholders to avoid crashes—was it ROM space, time, or complexity?
How are you communicating to players that hacked access beyond demo boundaries will crash (and that it’s expected)?
What feedback from demo players are you specifically seeking (controls, difficulty, exploration, performance, art style)?

open_questions.topic: Global points/mission restructuring and removal of “100 coin missions”
open_questions.context: Kaze states that “100 coin missions do not exist anymore” and that points are global now, implying a shift away from classic SM64 star/coin mission conventions.
questions: What does ‘points are global’ mean in RTYI: a unified currency across courses, a score system, or progression tracking replacing certain stars?
How did removing 100-coin stars change the game’s pacing and the value of exploration?
How do you keep optional exploration rewarding without the classic 100-coin star structure?
